item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513) Remote Control: Final 3D Printed Part Added
item.description:
I have completed the final 3D printed component for my Beogram 4002 (5513) remote control system. This piece fits into a 10mm opening on the remote control receiver board, allowing it to be secured using one of the main PCB’s screws. The image below shows the part with the screw in place: Once the remote control board is in place, the original screw can be used to fasten it. The cylindrical portion is designed to prevent the remote board from pressing against the component pins on the Beogram’s main PCB while ensuring a secure fit...

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513) Remote Control: Now With a 3D Printed Installation Tray
item.description:
This post continues the discussion about my Beogram 4002 (5513) remote control upgrade, specifically the receiver board insulation. My previous solution, using plastic foil, wasn’t ideal aesthetically. To address this, I designed a plastic tray that safeguards the receiver board from the main circuit board’s solder points. The tray is designed to click into place without additional screws. Here are some photos: Tray and board before assembly: The tray features three rectangular cutouts to provide clearance for the solder points...

item.title: Beogram 4002 Commander Remote Control: Installation Video
item.description:
My Beogram 4002 “Commander” remote control system has recently seen a surge in popularity, with multiple orders coming in over a short time. This could be linked to the Commander’s new compatibility with a specific Apple TV remote, allowing it to integrate with Apple devices in the same space. Designed for later models of the 4002 turntable with the keypad connector on the main circuit board (types 551x and 552x), I recently built three receivers over the weekend and shipped them out today, each packaged with a compatible Apple remote:..

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Installation of the Latest Version of the Beogram Commander Remote Control
item.description:
While restoring my Beogram 4002 (5513), I decided to improve the Beogram 4002 Commander remote control I had previously designed. I added a “pairing” feature to prevent conflicts with Apple TVs and other devices that use Apple remotes. To completely eliminate the need to touch the Beogram’s delicate keypad, I also included remote switching between 33 and 45 RPM. A detailed video about the latest version explains the functions and demonstrates the remote and its pairing process:..
